objects.name: Egregor Infection Chain and Payload Analysis
objects.description:
# Summary

Following the trend of ransomware operators also exfiltrating data is the Egregor ransomware family. Cybereason published their analysis of recent campaigns involving this ransomware.

# Threat Type

- Ransomware

# Overview

Cybereason has published their analysis of the Egregor ransomware and its infection chain. Campaigns begin with a phishing email with a malicious Word document attached. These maldocs deliver a commodity malware, such as Qbot, Ursnif or IcedID. The commodity malware is used for stealing sensitive data and lateral movement. Furthermore, CobaltStrike beacons are deployed for reconnaissance, privilege escalation, and lateral movement. Eventually the attacker compromises Active Directory and obtains domain admin privileges. With this access, scripts, DLLs, and additional files are downloaded from a C2 server. Included in these downloaded files are a batch file and a ZIP file. The batch file is used to download and execute the Egregor ransomware. The ZIP file contains the RClone client, masquerading as svchost, which is leveraged to exfiltrate files from the victim network. The Egregor ransomware can only be executed if it is passed a correct decryption key, otherwise execution will fail, increasing the difficulty of analysis. Victims are provided a short period of time to pay the ransomware, which is negotiated via chat. If the ransom goes unpaid, the stolen files are published on a Tor website operated by the attackers. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section. A link to a blog post by Group-IB regarding this ransomware family is also provided.

# Indicators of Compromise

- A complete list of IoCs can be found in the Reports section on the right. 

# Recommendations

- Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
- Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
- Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
- Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
- Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

# Reference

- https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs-egregor-ransomware 
- https://www.group-ib.com/blog/egregor

custom_objects.collectionWikiMarkdown:
# Summary

Following the trend of ransomware operators also exfiltrating data is the Egregor ransomware family. Cybereason published their analysis of recent campaigns involving this ransomware.

# Threat Type

- Ransomware

# Overview

Cybereason has published their analysis of the Egregor ransomware and its infection chain. Campaigns begin with a phishing email with a malicious Word document attached. These maldocs deliver a commodity malware, such as Qbot, Ursnif or IcedID. The commodity malware is used for stealing sensitive data and lateral movement. Furthermore, CobaltStrike beacons are deployed for reconnaissance, privilege escalation, and lateral movement. Eventually the attacker compromises Active Directory and obtains domain admin privileges. With this access, scripts, DLLs, and additional files are downloaded from a C2 server. Included in these downloaded files are a batch file and a ZIP file. The batch file is used to download and execute the Egregor ransomware. The ZIP file contains the RClone client, masquerading as svchost, which is leveraged to exfiltrate files from the victim network. The Egregor ransomware can only be executed if it is passed a correct decryption key, otherwise execution will fail, increasing the difficulty of analysis. Victims are provided a short period of time to pay the ransomware, which is negotiated via chat. If the ransom goes unpaid, the stolen files are published on a Tor website operated by the attackers. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section. A link to a blog post by Group-IB regarding this ransomware family is also provided.

# Indicators of Compromise

- A complete list of IoCs can be found in the Reports section on the right. 

# Recommendations

- Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
- Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
- Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
- Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
- Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

# Reference

- https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs-egregor-ransomware 
- https://www.group-ib.com/blog/egregor

Summary
Following the trend of ransomware operators also exfiltrating data is the Egregor ransomware family. Cybereason published their analysis of recent campaigns involving this ransomware.
Threat Type
Ransomware
Overview
Cybereason has published their analysis of the Egregor ransomware and its infection chain. Campaigns begin with a phishing email with a malicious Word document attached. These maldocs deliver a commodity malware, such as Qbot, Ursnif or IcedID. The commodity malware is used for stealing sensitive data and lateral movement. Furthermore, CobaltStrike beacons are deployed for reconnaissance, privilege escalation, and lateral movement. Eventually the attacker compromises Active Directory and obtains domain admin privileges. With this access, scripts, DLLs, and additional files are downloaded from a C2 server. Included in these downloaded files are a batch file and a ZIP file. The batch file is used to download and execute the Egregor ransomware. The ZIP file contains the RClone client, masquerading as svchost, which is leveraged to exfiltrate files from the victim network. The Egregor ransomware can only be executed if it is passed a correct decryption key, otherwise execution will fail, increasing the difficulty of analysis. Victims are provided a short period of time to pay the ransomware, which is negotiated via chat. If the ransom goes unpaid, the stolen files are published on a Tor website operated by the attackers. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section. A link to a blog post by Group-IB regarding this ransomware family is also provided.
Indicators of Compromise
A complete list of IoCs can be found in the Reports section on the right. 
Recommendations
Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
Reference
https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs-egregor-ransomware
